conclusion: Car A starts at velocity v₁ at t=0 and increases to velocity v₂ at t=t₁; Car B starts at velocity v₂ at t=0 and decreases to velocity v₁ at t=t₁; Both cars are moving in the same direction on a straight highway; We need to compare their average velocities during the time period from t=0 to t=t₁
Average velocity is the total displacement divided by the total time: v_avg = Δx/Δt; On a velocity-time graph, the displacement is equal to the area under the curve
Car A's initial velocity is v₁ and final velocity is v₂; The displacement is the area under curve A from t=0 to t=t₁
Car B's initial velocity is v₂ and final velocity is v₁; The displacement is the area under curve B from t=0 to t=t₁
Car A's curve is below the straight line connecting (0,v₁) to (t₁,v₂); Car B's curve is above the straight line connecting (0,v₂) to (t₁,v₁)
For Car A, the actual area is less than the linear approximation; For Car B, the actual area is more than the linear approximation
For linearly changing velocities, Car A's average velocity would be (v₁ + v₂)/2; Car B's average velocity would be (v₂ + v₁)/2; These are equal
The average velocity is the area under the velocity curve divided by the time duration: Car A: v_avg,A = Area under curve A/t₁; Car B: v_avg,B = Area under curve B/t₁
The areas under both curves sum to a rectangle with height (v₂-v₁) and width t₁
Since the blue intersection point appears to be at the midpoint of the time interval and velocity range, the areas under curves A and B are equal
The average velocities of Car A and Car B during the time period from t=0 to t=t₁ are equal
